cyclone.name: IRMA
cyclone.trajectory: Continuing west-northwest across the northern Leeward Islands, then toward the Turks & Caicos / southeast Bahamas and ultimately the Straits of Florida with a possible turn northward along or just off the Florida east coast late in the 5-day period
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: South Florida or the Florida Keys (most likely first U.S. land interaction)

weather_observation.watch_coast: Hurricane and tropical-storm watches confined to northern Hispaniola, Turks & Caicos, and southeast Bahamas
weather_observation.warning_coast: Hurricane warnings for northern Leeward Islands, Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico; no Florida warnings yet
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Northern Leeward Islands, Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, north coast of Hispaniola, Turks & Caicos, southeast and central Bahamas, Cuba, and potentially the Florida peninsula later in the period
weather_observation.wind: 8% chance of 34-kt winds within 5 days, with probabilities climbing rapidly beyond the 5-day window if Irma tracks near Florida; hurricane-force winds remain unlikely at this lead time but could increase with future advisories.
weather_observation.storm_surge: If Irma parallels or crosses the Florida east coast, a surge in excess of 3 ft is possible along the northeast Florida coastline, including the St. Johns River entrance.
weather_observation.rainfall: Heavy rains of 4–8 inches are possible early next week if the storm passes close to northeast Florida.
weather_observation.other_hazards: High surf, dangerous rip currents, and coastal erosion are likely to begin this weekend ahead of the storm’s closest approach.
